1507961-a.folder: 48th Street (West) #123 - Sixth Avenue - Seventh Avenue, north side, Manhattan, NY
1507961-a.title: 48th Street (West) #123 - Sixth Avenue - Seventh Avenue, north side

709523f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, north and across W. 48th Street, showing the N. E. corner of same, the row of buildings that are to be demolished.  Upon this site will be erected the U. S. Rubber Company Building.  This will complete the block.

View 3 is the same location at a later date.  Note the absence of the above identified structures.  Construc-tion work on the Avenue is for the finishing details of the Municipal Subway that runs underground.  This replaced the old Elevated Line.

View 1, 2 May 6, 1939
View 3, June 21, 1939

P.L. Sperr

709525f-a.text:
1220 to 1236 Sixth Avenue, east side, north from W. 48th to 49th Streets, showing a row of structures, several slightly improved and the Center Theatre. The latter (No. 1236) is a part of Rockefeller City and is at the S.E. corner of 49th Street. This, a losing venture, may be demolished and an office structure erected instead.

No. 2 shows the N.E. corner of 48th Street. The corner structure bears No's. 122O Sixth Avenue and 71 N. 48th Street. Adjoining same are two 4 story former private dwellings whose numbers are 69 and 67. Overhead on the Avenues is the elevated line that shortly will be demolished in its entirety.
June 20, 1938.
Views 1 a nd 2
P. L. Sperr

709525f-b.text:
1220 to 1236 Sixth Avenue, east side, north from W. 48th to 49th Streets, showing a row of structures, several slightly improved and the Center Theatre. The latter (No. 1236) is a part of Rockefeller City and is at the S.E. corner of 49th Street. This, a losing venture, may be demolished and an office structure erected instead.

No. 2 shows the N.E. corner of 48th Street. The corner structure bears No's. 122O Sixth Avenue and 71 N. 48th Street. Adjoining same are two 4 story former private dwellings whose numbers are 69 and 67. Overhead on the Avenues is the elevated line that shortly will be demolished in its entirety.
June 20, 1938.
Views 1 a nd 2
P. L. Sperr

709526f-a.text:
1220 to 123O Sixth Avenue, at adjoining and north of the N.E. corner of W. 48th Steet. All of these structures appear in View 1 whle No.2 shows only three, No's. 1220 to 1224.
At the rear of these buildings the R.K.O. Center Theatre is being erected. The Sixth Avenue "El" line in April 1939 will have disappeared and the brownstone buildings at this site ready for demolition. The New York Times of April 3, 1939 reports the immediate erection of a 20 story Rockefeller Center structure on this site, same cousummating this vast midtown comnercial and amusement center which started in 1931.
Occupancy is scheduled for March 1, 1940. An interesting feature will be the overlapping of the new building at the 8th floor on the steel work of the Center Theatre. The theatre was
constructed with this provison in mind.
March 18, 1932
Views: 1-2

P.L. Sperr

709527f-a.text:
Sixth Avenue, east side, north from W. 48th Street, showing prominently the excavation for the new Rodkefeller Center Building. This is at the N. E. corner and is to be titled "the U. S. Rubber Co. Building." The enclosure is provided for the public who, as quite obvious, enjoy watching the foundation construction. The publicity agent capitalized on this quirk and had the fence lettered "Sidewalk Superintendents Club". The insignia is titled, "De beste stuurlui staan aan wal", which translated is "The best pilots stand on the shore". This originated with the Netherlands Building, an adjoining Rockefeller Center unit.
Views 1,2: July 18, 193'
View 3: June 21, 1939
P. L. Sperr

Ed. Note -- Properly translates from Dutch as "Best mates stand ashore".

709529f-a.text:
Sixth Ave., east side, north from, but not including West 48th Street.
February 1, 1929.
L. Sperr.

709542f-a.text:
(1) anc (2)
Sixth Avenue, east side, from West 49th (left) to 48th (right) Street's, showing mainly the row of structures at the N.E. corner of the latter point. These are to be demolished for a new Rockefeller Center unit which will be known as the U. S. Rubber Building. To the left is the Center Theatre. The photographer is viewing southeastward from the opposite site of the Avenue. Note the surface conditions upon same resulting
from subway construction underground.
Forming a backdrop are two office structures in the block below, one of which is on 48th Street and the other on 47th Street.
View 1: May 6, 1939
View 2: June 21, 1939
P. L. Sperr
(3)
A more inclusive view from a vantage point above 49th Street. Note the Empire State Building in the background.
View 3 June 21, 1939
P.L. Sperr

709565f-a.text:
(1)
Sixth Ave., (not shown) between West 5Oth and 48th Streets and showing the future site of Radio City being cleared. Buildings shown on the right are on 48th Street, between Sixth and Fifth Aves; the parking lot includes the 49th Street side. Across the skyline (left to right) appears Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, Grand Central Building, Chrysler Building, Fred. F. French Building, Chanin Building. Ruppert Building, Lincoln Building, Lefcourt National Building and 500 Fifth Ave. Building. In the foreground appears a portion of the few buildings left on the east side of Sixth Ave. and which today (1937)
still remain, Radio City being built around them.
September 14, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, and showing the 50th Street station of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line. Building across the station roof is No. 1258 (old number.being 886) Sixth Ave., at the S.E. corner of 5Oth Street. This view shows on the left the three corners of Fifth Ave. and 49th Street, through the clearance at the N.W. corner.
September 14, 1931.

63-59 West 49th Street, north side, east from Sixth Avenue.
About 1913.

713334f-a.text:
(1)
72-38 West 48th Street, south side, east of Sixth Ave., as viewed across clearance for the R.K.O. Theatre, (formerly Roxy's, now (1937) The Center). Note the Empire State Building in the background.
JMne 28, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A view eastward from No. 52, (5-story brownstone building) and showing prominently Nos. 56-48, 42, and 40-38; 16 and 12- story building respectively; the larger of which is the Cellini Building.
July 23, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A limited view, and showing mainly Nos. 64-70, a 17-story loft building.
July 23, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

713335f-a.text:
(1)
48th Street, north side, east from but not including Sixth Ave. In the foreground, houses are being demolished for the construction of Rockefeller Centre. In the background may be seen the skyscraper at 444 Madison Ave. and, to its right, the new Waldorf-Astoria Hotel nearing completion.
May 27, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, at a later date, further eastward and showing a closer view of the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas.
March 28, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
Similar to No. 2, but at an earlier date.
October 18, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
